Definitions.Definition_Content: Let $K$ be a field (or, more generally, an integral domain) and let $\varphi: \mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow K$ be the canonical ring homomorphism. Furthermore, let $p \in \mathbb{N}$ be a generating element of the principal ideal $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$. Then $p$ is called the characteristic of $K$, and we write $p=\operatorname{char} K$.
A subring $T$ of a field $K$ is called a subfield if $T$ is a field itself.
The unique smallest subfield $P$ of a field $K$, given by the intersection of all subfields in $K$, is referred to as the prime (sub)field in $K$.

For a field $K$ of characteristic $p>0$, the map $\sigma: K \longrightarrow K, \quad a \longmapsto a^{p}$, which respects the addition on $K$, defines a homomorphism of fields known as the Frobenius homomorphism of $K$.

Theorems.Theorem_Content: Let $K$ be a field and $P \subset K$ its prime subfield. Then: (i) char $K=p>0 \Longleftrightarrow P \simeq \mathbb{F}_{p}$ for $p$ prime. (ii) $\operatorname{char} K=0 \Longleftrightarrow P \simeq \mathbb{Q}$. In particular, up to isomorphism, the only prime subfields that can occur, are $\mathbb{F}_{p}$ for a prime number $p$, as well as $\mathbb{Q}$.

Let $p$ be a prime number and $R$ an integral domain of characteristic $p$ (or, more generally, a ring satisfying $p \cdot 1=0$ ). Then, for elements $a, b \in R$ and $r \in \mathbb{N}$, the binomial formula takes the following form: $(a+b)^{p^{r}}=a^{p^{r}}+b^{p^{r}}, \quad(a-b)^{p^{r}}=a^{p^{r}}-b^{p^{r}} .$
